title: Battlefield Redsec Map - Exploring Fort Lyndon And All Locations

                Battlefield Redsec is Battlefield 6's new, free-to-play battle royale game. Redsec's Fort Lyndon is a large map set in Los Angeles. The map features 21 main points of interest, including a marina and a golf course. In this guide, we highlight the full Fort Lyndon map and some recommended locations to loot.Redsec's Fort Lyndon offers helicopters, tanks, and destruction just like you'd expect from a Battlefield game. The map also includes one of the deadliest battle royale circles, with fire that will instantly kill you if you touch it. To avoid death, you'll want to learn the map locations and stay ahead of all the circle collapses.The full Fort Lyndon map can be viewed below. The battle royale map features a variety of different landscapes for your fights. This includes neighborhoods, military bases, industrial areas, a marina, and more.Season 1 of Battlefield 6 includes a battle pass filled with skins and other rewards, as well as new weapons and attachments to unlock.All Fort Lyndon main POIsMarinaEvac AlphaOcean ParkLighthouseDowntownBoutique DistrictEvac BravoVista HillsCrash SiteDefense NexusSecurity GateGolf CourseGround ZeroLyndon OilworksRedline StorageTreatment PlantArea 22BChemical StorageThe SealRadar SiteCombat TrainingFort Lyndon recommended loot locationsThere are plenty of locations to explore and loot. If you're just starting out, you might want to land somewhere that gives you plenty of loot and cover. The houses in Vista Hill are a good option, as well as the buildings of Downtown or the Boutique District.If your strategy is to lay low by landing on the outer edges of the map, you can try visiting Combat Training or Evac Bravo for some decent loot. You'll want to keep an eye on the circle, though. Landing on the edges of the map can be risky, depending on where the circle goes next.Golf Course is a fun location with a mix of buildings and various open greens of the course itself.For open sightlines to snipe, you might want to consider landing on the hilltops of the map. Fort Lyndon's Radar Site and the mountains around The Seal can offer nice elevated views of your surroundings.The Marina lets you fight across the beaches of Cali, and you can use boats to fight or traverse along the map's coast.For full recommendations, make sure to check out our guide for Fort Lyndon's best landing spots.Scroll down below for a closer look at some of Fort Lyndon's points of interest. For more, make sure to check out our Battlefield 6 guide hub.

title: How To Expand Inventory In The Outer Worlds 2 - Add Weapon, Grenade, And Inhaler Slots

                Are you scratching your head because you can't seem to unlock more weapon slots in The Outer Worlds 2? It's not just weapons, mind you. The types of grenades and medical inhalers that you can equip at any given time tend to be very limited as well.Table of Contents [hide]How to unlock more Outer Worlds 2 equipment slots Armor mods that grant bonus equipment slotsHow to apply armor modsPerks that grant bonus equipment slotsHow to unlock more Outer Worlds 2 equipment slots There are a couple of ways to unlock additional item slots in the game:One option is to socket mods that grant an extra slot. Note that this effect remains active as long as you have that gear piece equipped.Another option is to choose the right perks. Note that this effect is permanent.Armor mods that grant bonus equipment slotsIf you want to unlock more weapon slots in The Outer Worlds 2, as well as slots for your grenades and inhalers, then you could opt to find the following mods:Extra Holster - Gain an additional weapon slot.Grenade Bandolier - Gain an additional grenade slot.Extra Primer Port - Gain an additional medical inhaler slot.These items are normally sold by vendors in settlements. Alternatively, you might be able to loot them from certain enemies or containers.Different kinds of mods for helmets grant bonus slots.How to apply armor modsOnce you have a mod, you can attach it to a valid helmet/headgear by interacting with a workbench. Select the Mods menu, then choose an option that you'd like to socket to a helmet. Just remember a couple of caveats:Any mod that you attach to an item cannot be removed. Any new mod that you apply will destroy the previous one.If you switch to a different helmet that doesn't have the necessary mod, you'll lose the effect and the extra slot.Attach mods via workbenches to gain their effects.Perks that grant bonus equipment slotsIf you want a more permanent solution to this issue, then you can select the right perks:Commando:  Grants an additional weapon slot.Requires Melee 1 or Guns 1.Grenadier:  Grants an additional throwable item slot. Also grants +10% explosives damage.Requires Explosives 2.Pharm-Thusiast:  Grants an additional primer slot, allowing you to gain the effects of multiple primers at once.The total toxicity of all primers used simultaneously will be combined upon activation.-25% toxicity received from inhalers.Requires Medical 2.That does it for our guide on how to increase slots for your weapons, grenades, and inhalers in The Outer Worlds 2. While you're fiddling around with your equipment, you might want to learn about various unique weapons, unique armors/outfits, and unique helmets.

title: Game Boy Coding Adventure Sounds Like A Cool Book For Hobbyist Retro Devs

                                                                                                                                                               Hobbyist game developers and tinkerers who love the original Game Boy have a cool new book to pore over. Game Boy Coding Adventure is the latest release from No Starch Press, a publisher specializing in how-to books about computing and gaming. This massive, 456-page book teaches you how to make Game Boy games, but not with popular modern tools like GB Studio; this is a walkthrough for coding games and hardware functions in assembly, just like developers in the early '90s.Game Boy Coding Adventure is available for $50 in paperback and $35 on Kindle.                                 Game Boy Coding Adventure                                                                $50                                                                                                                                                                                    Game Boy Coding Adventure was written by industry veteran Maximilien Dagois. It's pitched as a comprehensive guide to Game Boy development, as demonstrated by the subtitle: Learn Assembly and Master the Original 8-Bit Handheld.It's not solely geared toward coding and designing games. You'll learn what makes the Game Boy tick and how it interacts with cartridges. Though mainly focused on the original Game Boy DMG and Game Boy Pocket, the book has sections on GBC, Super Game Boy, and accessories like the Game Boy Printer.The Game Boy's technical limitations required game developers to write in assembly, which isn't a defined programming language like Java or C++. Assembly is essentially a readable version of binary machine code, so Game Boy developers were communicating directly with the handheld's processing chip.Game Boy Coding Adventure teaches you how to write and debug code with RGBDS, the leading open source assembler for GB and GBC software and hardware projects. You'll learn about frame pacing, programming controls, and creating sound channels. Later chapters cover more in-depth topics such as memory banking and serial communication.The Game Boy's 8-bit graphics are built from a series of 8x8 tiles. The book teaches you all about tiles and how they are assembled by VRAM into backgrounds, windows, color palettes, and sprites--and how to animate sprites. All of the projects included in this book work on real Game Boy hardware.It's pretty awesome that this book exists and that it was picked up and released by No Starch Press, a publisher with a strong track record with tech and gaming how-to books. No Starch Press previously published a highly rated beginner's guide to modding Game Boy hardware. If you're interested in joining the Game Boy modding scene, you can snag the 256-page paperback edition for $25.                      No Starch Press has published books on a wide variety of programming languages and game development tools. Invent Your Own Computer Games with Python is one of the publisher's most popular game development books. There's also Mission Python, which teaches teenagers how to create a space adventure game. No Starch Press is no stranger to niche game development tools, either. There are guides on making interactive, text-based adventures with Twine and puzzle-platformers with PuzzleScript. The publisher has an entire series of books on Scratch, the popular block-based programming language created by MIT Media Lab.Other Game Boy books that are worth adding to your collection include The Game Boy Encyclopedia and The History of the Game Boy. The Game Boy Encyclopedia by Chris Scullion covers every game released in North America and Europe for GB and GBC; the hardcover edition is discounted to $24 (was $43) at Amazon. The History of the Game Boy is an (unofficial) behind-the-scenes look at the creation of the Game Boy and its lifecycle from 1989-1998. Written by Florent Gorges, this well-researched book is based on interviews with developers who worked on the Game Boy. It was published in English for the first time alongside The History of the Famicom/NES last September.Speaking of NES, a book dedicated to learning the 8-bit home console's 6502 Assembler language released last year. Classic Game Programming on the NES is available for $40.47 (was $50) at Amazon. You may also want to check out the Code the Classics series, which teaches you how to make retro games using Python and Pygame Zero. Code the Classics Volume 1 teaches you how to make games inspired by classics from the '70s and early '80s, and Volume 2 focuses solely on the '80s. The Second Editions of both volumes were published by Raspberry Pi Press last summer.
